Forms: powder for IV, tablet (co-formulated with TMP)
Star_Features:
resistance development to TMP-SMX is limited by the 2 drugs acting synergistically blocking sequential steps in folic acid synthesis 
resistance in streptococcus (e.g., do not use for strep throat), but effective against MSSA and many CA-MRSA strains
MOA:
sulfonamides are bacteriostatic agents that compete with PABA 
(competitive inhibitor) and folate synthesis inhibitor of dihydropteroate synthase
Contraindications: patients <2 mo.; megaloblastic anemia due to folate deficiency;
Cellular_Target: sulfamethoxazole- dihydropteroate synthase \n trimethoprim- dihydrofolate reductase
Adverse_Reactions::
hypersensitivity-Stevens Johnson syndrome  “sulfa drug”
crystalluria – crystal formation in the kidneys causing organ damage
anemia = decreased RBC
 rash*, pruritus*,

Brand: Macrobid™ (macrocrystal formulation better tolerated in GI), Furadantin™, Macrodantin™
MOA:
activity depends on a bacterial nitroreductase reduction of the nitro group 
\n the radical product reacts with O2 forming O2\n that causes DNA damage.
Adverse_Reactions:: GI irritant; causes urine to turn dark brown

Star_Features: urinary bacteria\nachieves very high urinary concentration (>2000 mg/mL) minimizing resistance development

MOA: prodrugs that exert their toxic effect in bacteria via e reduction of the nitro group by bacterial nitroreductase (required for prodrug activation) \n nitro radical interacts w/ the DNA causing the strand break
Adverse_Reactions::
not well tolerated by GI system (severe nausea)  
\ncan induce vaginal candidiasis requiring antifungal treatment \n disulfiram reaction

Brand: Cipro™ is rapidly eliminated in urine \nCipro XR (extended release) tablets -  taken once daily
Structural_Features:
fluorine atom – located at the C-6 position; adds lipophilicity aiding in 
outer membrane penetration and increasing binding affinity to mutated 
DNA gyrase 
\npiperazine ring – located at the C-7 position; increases bioactivity 
spectrum including Gram (+) bacteria; increases half-life making it useful for systemic infection
MOA: Quinolones are bactericidal agents that inhibit DNA gyrase (topoisomerase) inhibition makes a bacterium’s DNA inaccessible (for replication, protein synthesis) and leads to cell death
Spectrum: MSSA, PEK, PIDDLY, SACE, Pseudomonas, Atypicals

Star_Features: the S-enantiomer of ofloxacin and is 2x as potent • due to its broad activity spectrum, often given empirically
Structural_Features:
characterized by an additional C-8 substituent to FQ ring 
\ndeveloped becas S. pneumoniae (pneumococcus) and expanded atypical coverage  
\nused for bacterial causes of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP):
Spectrum: MSSA, Strep, S. pneumo, PEK, PIDDLY, SACE, Pseudomonas, Atypicals

Star_Features:
only FQ that covers anaerobes
\nprimarily eliminated in feces (hepatic) 
• low urinary excretion → only FQ not used to treat UTIs 
• no dosage adjustment is necessary in patients with renal impairment
Spectrum: MSSA, Strep, S. pneumo, PEK, PIDDLY, SACE, Anaerobes, Atypicals

Star_Features: for SSSI and covers MRSA and Pseudomonas
Structural_Features: newest FQ class with only 1 ionizable group (COOH); all previous approved FQ are zwitterionic
Spectrum: MSSA, MRSA, Strep, S. pneumo, PEK, PIDDLY, SACE, Pseudomonas

Star_Features: poor oral absorption; rapidly excreted\nunstable to stomach acid = IV (Na+/K+ salt) or IM (procaine/benzathine salt) injection used
Adverse_Reactions::
most serious ADR is an immediate IgE-mediated anaphylaxis (Type I  hypersensitivity)
or IV (delayed) hypersensitivity) reaction can cause Coombs + hemolytic anemia,: \npenicillins may also react with proteins on the surface of RBC cell membrane; once attached, the immune system begins 
destroying the RBCs that could lead to anemia (i.e., Coombs + hemolytic anemia).
\n

Star_Features: more acid-stable than PEN for oral dosing

short half-life (0.5 hrs); blood levels may be prolonged by concurrent administration of 
probenecid which blocks the renal tubular secretion of penicillins
Structural_Features: resistance to B-lactamase hydrolysis is caused by poor binding (steric hindrance) due to the C-6 sidechain substituents:
Spectrum: MSSA, Strep, S. pneumo, Oral = Anaerobes

Pharmacodynamics: all penicillins except NAF are excreted in urine \n eliminated primarily feces

Star_Features: often given with the B-lactamase inhibitor sulbactam \n synergy with aminoglycosides for meningitis infections (e.g., listeriosis)
Contraindications: higher risk of rash in patients with mononucleosis
Spectrum: Strep, S. pneumo, Enterococcus, + VRE, PEK, ≈ PIDDLY, Anaerobes
Adverse_Reactions:: diarrhea common due to incomplete absorption (kills intestinal microflora) → watch for CDAD  \n rashes occur more often with AMP and AMX than with other penicillins.

Star_Features:
better oral bioavailability than ampicillin - less diarrhea b/c more 
complete absorption 
\n B-lactamase susceptible; often given with the B-lactamase inhibitor clavulanic acid
Contraindications: higher risk of rash in patients with mononucleosis
Spectrum: Strep, S. pneumo, Enterococcus, + VRE, PEK, ≈ PIDDLY, Anaerobes
Adverse_Reactions:: diarrhea (due to clavulanic acid) \n rashes occur more often with AMP and AMX than with other penicillins.

Spectrum: MSSA, Strep, S. pneumo, Enterococcus, + VRE, PEK, ≈ PIDDLY, Anaerobes
MSSA, Strep, S. pneumo, Enterococcus, + VRE, PEK, ≈ PIDDLY, Anaerobes

Star_Features: disodium formulated (precaution in pts with restricted Na intake \n co-formulated with the -lactamase inhibitor clavulanic acid
Spectrum: MSSA, Strep, S. pneumo, Enterococcus, + VRE, PEK, PIDDLY, SACE, Pseudomonas, Anaerobes
